trans-unit.source: Deploy from Visual Studio
trans-unit.target: Deploy from Visual Studio

trans-unit.source: Create a project in Visual Studio to manage your Logic app.
trans-unit.target: Create a project in Visual Studio to manage your Logic app.

trans-unit.source: Deploy from Visual Studio
trans-unit.target: Deploy from Visual Studio

trans-unit.source: Although the <link><linkText>Azure Portal</linkText><title></title></link> gives you a great way to design and manage your Logic apps, you may also want to deploy your Logic app from Visual Studio instead.
trans-unit.target: Although the <link><linkText>Azure Portal</linkText><title></title></link> gives you a great way to design and manage your Logic apps, you may also want to deploy your Logic app from Visual Studio instead.

trans-unit.source: There are a couple key capabilities this enables:
trans-unit.target: There are a couple key capabilities this enables:

trans-unit.source: Store your Logic app alongside the other assets in your Solution, so it can contain all aspects of your application
trans-unit.target: Store your Logic app alongside the other assets in your Solution, so it can contain all aspects of your application

trans-unit.source: Keep your Logic app definition checked into source control so that you can use TFS or Git to track revisions to it
trans-unit.target: Keep your Logic app definition checked into source control so that you can use TFS or Git to track revisions to it

trans-unit.source: You have to have the Azure SDK 2.7 or later installed in order to follow the steps below.
trans-unit.target: You have to have the Azure SDK 2.7 or later installed in order to follow the steps below.

trans-unit.source: Find <link><linkText>the latest SDK for VS</linkText><title></title></link> here.
trans-unit.target: Find <link><linkText>the latest SDK for VS</linkText><title></title></link> here.

trans-unit.source: Create a project
trans-unit.target: Create a project

trans-unit.source: Go to the File menu and select New > Project (or, you can go to Add and then select New project to add it to an existing solution)
trans-unit.target: Go to the File menu and select New > Project (or, you can go to Add and then select New project to add it to an existing solution)

trans-unit.source: <linkText>File menu</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>File menu</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the dialog find Cloud and then select Azure Resource Group.
trans-unit.target: In the dialog find Cloud and then select Azure Resource Group.

trans-unit.source: Type a Name and then click OK.
trans-unit.target: Type a Name and then click OK.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Add new project</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Add new project</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You now need to select if you want an Logic app or Logic app + API app.
trans-unit.target: You now need to select if you want an Logic app or Logic app + API app.

trans-unit.source: Selecting Logic app requires you to point to existing API's.
trans-unit.target: Selecting Logic app requires you to point to existing API's.

trans-unit.source: If you select Logic app + API app then you can also create an new, empty, API app at the same time.
trans-unit.target: If you select Logic app + API app then you can also create an new, empty, API app at the same time.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Select Azure template</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Select Azure template</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Once you have selected your Template hit OK.
trans-unit.target: Once you have selected your Template hit OK.

trans-unit.source: Now your Logic app project will be added to your solution.
trans-unit.target: Now your Logic app project will be added to your solution.

trans-unit.source: You should see the deployment in the Solution Explorer:
trans-unit.target: You should see the deployment in the Solution Explorer:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Deployment</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Deployment</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Configuring your Logic app
trans-unit.target: Configuring your Logic app

trans-unit.source: Once you have a project you can edit the definition of your Logic app inside VS.
trans-unit.target: Once you have a project you can edit the definition of your Logic app inside VS.

trans-unit.source: Click on the JSON file in the solution explorer.
trans-unit.target: Click on the JSON file in the solution explorer.

trans-unit.source: You will see a placeholder definition that you can fill in with your application's logic.
trans-unit.target: You will see a placeholder definition that you can fill in with your application's logic.

trans-unit.source: It's recommended to use parameters throughout your definition.
trans-unit.target: It's recommended to use parameters throughout your definition.

trans-unit.source: This will be useful if you want to deploy to both a development and production environment.
trans-unit.target: This will be useful if you want to deploy to both a development and production environment.

trans-unit.source: In that case, you should put all environment-specific configuration in the .param file, and the parameters instead of the actual strings.
trans-unit.target: In that case, you should put all environment-specific configuration in the .param file, and the parameters instead of the actual strings.

trans-unit.source: Today, Visual Studio does not have a built-in designer, so if you'd like to use a graphical interface (as opposed to writing JSON), you will need to use the Azure Portal.
trans-unit.target: Today, Visual Studio does not have a built-in designer, so if you'd like to use a graphical interface (as opposed to writing JSON), you will need to use the Azure Portal.

trans-unit.source: If you previously created a Logic app inside the Azure Portal and now want to check it in to source control, you can do that one of 3 different ways:
trans-unit.target: If you previously created a Logic app inside the Azure Portal and now want to check it in to source control, you can do that one of 3 different ways:

trans-unit.source: Go to Code view in the portal and copy the definition.
trans-unit.target: Go to Code view in the portal and copy the definition.

trans-unit.source: Use the Logic apps <link><linkText>REST API</linkText><title></title></link> to get the definition.
trans-unit.target: Use the Logic apps <link><linkText>REST API</linkText><title></title></link> to get the definition.

trans-unit.source: Use Azure Resource manager powershell, specifically the [Get-AzureResource command](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn654579.aspx) to download the definition.
trans-unit.target: Use Azure Resource manager powershell, specifically the [Get-AzureResource command](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn654579.aspx) to download the definition.

trans-unit.source: Deploying your Logic app
trans-unit.target: Deploying your Logic app

trans-unit.source: Finally, after you have configured your app you can deploy directly from Visual Studio in just a couple steps.
trans-unit.target: Finally, after you have configured your app you can deploy directly from Visual Studio in just a couple steps.

trans-unit.source: Right-click on the deployment in the Solution Explorer and go to Deploy > New deployment...
trans-unit.target: Right-click on the deployment in the Solution Explorer and go to Deploy > New deployment...

trans-unit.source: <linkText>New deployment</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>New deployment</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You will be prompted to sign in to your Azure subscription(s).
trans-unit.target: You will be prompted to sign in to your Azure subscription(s).

trans-unit.source: Now you need to choose the details of the resource group that you want to deploy the Logic app to.
trans-unit.target: Now you need to choose the details of the resource group that you want to deploy the Logic app to.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Deploy to resource group</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Deploy to resource group</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Be sure to select the right template and parameters files for the resource group (for example if you are deploying to a production environment you'll want to choose the production parameters file).
trans-unit.target: Be sure to select the right template and parameters files for the resource group (for example if you are deploying to a production environment you'll want to choose the production parameters file).

trans-unit.source: The status of the deployment will appear in the Output window (you may need to choose Azure Provisioning.
trans-unit.target: The status of the deployment will appear in the Output window (you may need to choose Azure Provisioning.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Output</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Output</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the future you can revise your Logic app in source control and use Visual Studio to deploy new versions.
trans-unit.target: In the future you can revise your Logic app in source control and use Visual Studio to deploy new versions.

trans-unit.source: Note that if you modify the definition in the Azure Portal directly, the next time that you deploy from Visual Studio those changes will be overriden.
trans-unit.target: Note that if you modify the definition in the Azure Portal directly, the next time that you deploy from Visual Studio those changes will be overriden.

trans-unit.source: If you do not want to use Visual Studio, but still want to having tooling to deploy your Logic app from source control you can always use the <link><linkText>API</linkText><title></title></link> or <link><linkText>Powershell</linkText><title></title></link> directly to automate your deployments.
trans-unit.target: If you do not want to use Visual Studio, but still want to having tooling to deploy your Logic app from source control you can always use the <link><linkText>API</linkText><title></title></link> or <link><linkText>Powershell</linkText><title></title></link> directly to automate your deployments.

trans-unit.source: test
trans-unit.target: test
